publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-12-11 10:29:26 -0500.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Materials found in collection; provenance is unknown. The accession number associated with this gift is 1950.103.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection had not been arranged by an archivist. Materials are in the order in which they were received from the donor.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Stephanie Oursler is a progressive, feminist and labor activist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Stephanie Oursler Papers; TAM 298; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains circulars, reports, and other internal documents and printed ephemera including produced by and relating to several New Left organizations, principally based in New York City, including the women's and peace movements, files on sexual discrimination in employment and in the workplace, the Black Panther Party, essays submitted to the "New York Element" of the Peace and Freedom Party, and documents relating to the negotiation of the first contract of the Social Service Employees Union. Some of the material is authored by Oursler. One notable document is a 16 pp. typescript on the relations between the SDA (Social Democracy of America -- possibly referring to or a shortening of the Socialist Party-Social Democratic Federation) and the Young Socialist League, probably written in the mid to late 1950s.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by Stephanie Oursler was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
